EXTRACTED VALUE: Multiplayer for the minigames would have made a great addition to extend the replay value of the game.
At World's End's slick visuals don't make up for the dull, repetitive combat and uninspired mission structure.
Two quid too expensive, seven years late and lacking the 'aw' factor if its predecessor. [Issue #22, p.114]
Microsoft's Live Arcade offerings are generally well worth the asking price, but Feeding Frenzy, sadly, isn't one of them.
Not even the allure of shiny robots with guns for arms can liven up this mind-numbingly simplistic and repetitive over-the-shoulder shooter.
Save for the cooperative mode, there’s not much here worthy of a gamer’s time that is devoted to buying and renting the best games.
The controls are great, but with nothing to do in terms of content, things ultimately fall short.
If it had something, anything new I feel like I could recommend, I'd fully endorse it, but I can't do that here.
Party Animals completely lacks what made the first Viva Pinata so endearing.
If Gamerscore records and leaderboards are that important to you, then go wild. Otherwise, save your money for the next Xbox Live Arcade game.
Painfully lacking in every area, lacking any thrill factor, excitement or variety. [Jan 2007, p.90]
A solid game, but its career mode is flawed and the gameplay is a strange mix of complex controls and arcade-like knockdowns.
About as fun as chiseling "HATE" into your eyes with a scalpel. [Issue 10, p.106]
The music isn't bad and the gameplay is fun enough, but the track list is fairly short with only ten pieces. [June 2007, p.69]
TNA iMPACT! has a great license and great characters, it just doesn't use either of them correctly.
There is so much mindless shooting and wandering in Bullet Witch that when you actually are having fun, it feels accidental. [Mar 2007, p.104]
